code:
try:
    filter(lambda client: client.screenName == search, clients)[0]
except IndexError:

text: You could use a generator expression,

code: client=next(client for client in clients if client.screenName == search)

text: but not that you still looping, just in a different way.
Note: If no client satisfies the condition client.screenName == search then the above will raise a StopIteration exception.
This is different than your for-loop, which falls out of the loop without returning anything.
Depending on your situation, raising an exception might be better than failing silently.
If you do not want a default value instead of a StopIteration exception, then you could use the 2-parameter version of next:

code:
client=next(client for client in clients if client.screenName == search, 
            default_value)

code:
>>> [e for e in l if e.screenName == 'b']
[<__main__.Client instance at 0x2e52b0>]

text: Now, just get the first - and assumedly only - element:

code:
>>> [e for e in l if e.screenName == 'b'][0]
<__main__.Client instance at 0x2e52b0>
>>> c = [e for e in l if e.screenName == 'b'][0]
>>> c.screenName
'b'

text: This is pretty short and IMHO elegant but can be less efficient because the list comprehension will iterate over all the list.
If you do want to avoid this overhead, you can get an generator instead of a new list using parenthesis instead of square brackets:

code:
>>> g = (e for e in l if e.screenName == 'b')
>>> g
<generator object <genexpr> at 0x2e5440>
>>> g.next()
<__main__.Client instance at 0x2e52b0>

text: However, note that the next() method can be called just once.

text: This requires you define a generic find function which would work for all types of lists like thus:

code:
def find(f, seq):
  """Return first item in sequence where f(item) == True."""
  for item in seq:
    if f(item): 
      return item
